skill.name: virtual-environment
skill.description: Check and create virtual environments for projects that need them. Use when starting Python/Node projects, or when dependency isolation is needed. Activates for Python, Node.js, and similar ecosystems.
skill.summary: Check and create virtual environments for projects that need them. Use when starting Python/Node pro...
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: This skill is a pure documentation resource with no executable code. It provides guidance on virtual environment management using standard tools like venv, Poetry, Pipenv, Conda, and npm. No scripts, network calls, or file operations beyond reading project metadata.

content.value_statement: Projects need isolated dependency environments to avoid conflicts. This skill helps you detect when virtual environments are needed and how to set them up correctly for Python, Node.js, and other ecosystems.
actual_capabilities: Detect project type from files like requirements.txt, package.json, pyproject.toml
Check if virtual environment already exists
Create Python venv or activate Poetry/Pipenv environments
Provide .gitignore recommendations for virtual environment folders
limitations: Cannot execute shell commands or install packages directly
Cannot modify project files or create new ones
Does not manage environment variables or .env files

output_examples.input: Check if this project needs a virtual environment
output: This project has a requirements.txt file, so it needs a virtual environment for Python dependencies.
Recommended: Use venv (built-in) or Poetry (for modern Python projects).
To create a venv: python -m venv .venv

best_practices: Always create a new virtual environment for each project to avoid dependency conflicts
Add virtual environment folders (.venv/, node_modules/) to .gitignore before committing
Use Poetry or Pipenv for Python projects that need reproducible dependency specifications
anti_patterns: Installing packages globally instead of in virtual environments
Sharing virtual environment folders between projects
Committing node_modules or .venv folders to version control

faq.question: What is a virtual environment?
faq.answer: An isolated directory that contains its own Python packages, separate from system-wide installations.

faq.question: Do I need a virtual environment?
faq.answer: Yes, when your project has dependencies that might conflict with other projects or system packages.

faq.question: Which tool should I use for Python?
faq.answer: Use venv for simple projects, Poetry for modern dependency management, or Pipenv for a balance of both.

faq.question: Is this skill safe to use?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill only provides documentation and guidance. It does not execute commands or modify files.

faq.question: Does this work with Windows?
faq.answer: Yes, it covers Windows PowerShell commands including .venv\Scripts\activate.

faq.question: What about Node.js projects?
faq.answer: Node.js uses node_modules for dependency isolation. This skill explains npm, yarn, and pnpm installation.
